title: Porto Velho
text:
Porto Velho (, "Old Port") is the <a href="capital%20%28political%29">capital</a> of the <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>ian <a href="States%20of%20Brazil">state</a> of <a href="Rond%C3%B4nia">Rondônia</a>, in the upper <a href="Amazon%20River">Amazon River</a> basin, and a Catholic Metropolitan Archbishopric. The population is 539,354 people (as of the <a href="Brazilian%20Institute%20of%20Geography%20and%20Statistics">IBGE</a> 2020 estimation). Located on the <a href="border">border</a> of Rondônia and the state of <a href="Amazonas%20State%2C%20Brazil">Amazonas</a>, the town is an important trading center for <a href="cassiterite">cassiterite</a>, the mining of which represents the most important economic activity in the <a href="region">region</a>, as well as a transportation and communication center. It is on the eastern shore of the <a href="Madeira%20River">Madeira River</a>, one of the main <a href="tributary">tributaries</a> of the <a href="Amazon%20River">Amazon River</a>. It is also Rondônia's largest city, and the largest state capital of Brazil by area.
The municipality occupies most of the border between Amazonas and Rondônia, and is both the westernmost and northernmost city in the state.
History.
Officially founded on October 2, 1914, Porto Velho was founded by pioneers around 1907, during the construction of the <a href="Madeira-Mamor%C3%A9%20Railroad">Madeira-Mamoré railroad</a>. After the <a href="railroad">railroad</a> was completed, the local population was about one thousand inhabitants; its buildings were chiefly the railway's installations and the wooden houses of the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> (mainly <a href="Barbadian%20people">Barbadian</a>) workers - hence the name of the town's largest district by then, "Bajan Hill" or "Barbados Town", nowadays called the "Alto do Bode".
During the first sixty years, the city's <a href="Urban%20planning">development</a> was directly connected to the railway's activities. The town prospered during the <a href="Natural%20rubber">rubber</a> boom, but then when low-cost <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>n rubber made rubber from the <a href="Amazon%20Basin">Amazon</a> uncompetitive, the region's <a href="Economics">economy</a> ground to a halt. Cities like <a href="Santo%20Ant%C3%B4nio%20do%20Madeira">Santo Antônio do Madeira</a>, which had a <a href="tram">tram</a> line and a weekly <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a> by the time of Porto Velho's foundation, are nothing but ruins nowadays.
Porto Velho's survival is associated with the better conditions of the area where it was built, its easy access by the river and its harbor: these were all considerations in the choice of Porto Velho as the capital of the newly formed Federal <a href="Territory%20%28country%20subdivision%29">Territory</a> of Guaporé, in 1943. Only with the beginning of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> was there another cycle of progress in the region. When the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied forces</a> lost control over the Malaysian rubber, Amazon's was needed due to the <a href="war%20effort">war effort</a>. This produced what is known in Brazil as the "second <a href="rubber%20boom">rubber boom</a>". But when the war ended, the region's economy once again came to a halt.
Porto Velho's modern <a href="history">history</a> begins with the discovery of <a href="cassiterite">cassiterite</a> around the city, and of <a href="gold">gold</a> on the <a href="Madeira%20River">Madeira River</a>, at the end of the 1950s. In addition, the government's decision to allow large cattle farms in the territory began a trend of migration into the city. Almost one million people moved to Rondônia, and Porto Velho's population increased to three hundred thousand. This intense migration caused much trouble for the city. Among many other problems, the suburban boroughs, for example, are nothing but <a href="shanty%20town">shanty town</a>s.
Its <a href="Sacred%20Heart%20of%20Jesus%20Cathedral%2C%20Porto%20Velho">Catedral Metropolitana Sagrado Coração de Jesus</a>, is the <a href="cathedral">cathedral</a> archiepiscopal see of a Latin Catholic jurisdiction that started on May 1, 1925 as the vast Amazonian <a href="Territorial%20Prelature%20of%20Porto%20Velho">Territorial Prelature of Porto Velho</a> on territories split off from the then <a href="Diocese%20of%20Amazonas">Diocese of Amazonas</a> and <a href="Diocese%20of%20S%C3%A3o%20Lu%C3%ADz%20de%20C%C3%A1ceres">Diocese of São Luíz de Cáceres</a> and lost parts of it to three new <a href="Territorial%20prelature">Territorial prelature</a>s before being promoted first bishopric (Diocese of Porto Velho) and on October 4, 1982 promoted as Metropolitan <a href="Archdiocese%20of%20Porto%20Velho">Archdiocese of Porto Velho</a>.
Geography.
Climate.
Porto Velho features a <a href="tropical%20monsoon%20climate">tropical monsoon climate</a> (climate type "Am") under the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>. The temperatures tend to be relatively consistent throughout the course of the year, with average daily temperatures typically between 25 and 26 degrees Celsius. The dry season is short and covers the months of June, July and August. Porto Velho is particularly wet from November through April, averaging roughly of rain per month in each of these months. According to the Brazilian National Institute of Meteorology (INMET), between 1961 and 1990 the lowest temperature recorded in Porto Velho was in July 1975, and the highest reached in August 1969.
Vegetation.
The Amazon has over half of the planet's remaining <a href="rainforest">rainforest</a>s and is the largest and most species-rich tract of <a href="tropical%20rainforest">tropical rainforest</a> in the <a href="world">world</a>. Wet tropical forests are the most species-rich <a href="biome">biome</a>, and tropical forests in the <a href="Americas">Americas</a> are consistently more species-rich than wet forests in <a href="Africa">Africa</a> and <a href="Asia">Asia</a>. As the largest tract of tropical rainforest in the Americas, the Amazonian rainforests have unparalleled <a href="biodiversity">biodiversity</a>.
More than one third of all species in the world live in the Amazon Rainforest.
Conservation.
The municipality contains what is left of the <a href="Rio%20Madeira%20Sustainable%20Yield%20Forest">Rio Madeira Sustainable Yield Forest</a> (B) and (C), created in 1990.
It contains the <a href="Lago%20do%20Cuni%C3%A3%20Extractive%20Reserve">Lago do Cuniã Extractive Reserve</a>, created in 1999.
It contains part of the strictly-protected <a href="Cuni%C3%A3%20Ecological%20Station">Cuniã Ecological Station</a>, an area of savannah parkland.
It holds all of the strictly protected <a href="Serra%20dos%20Tr%C3%AAs%20Irm%C3%A3os%20Ecological%20Station">Serra dos Três Irmãos Ecological Station</a>.
It contains part of the <a href="Mapinguari%20National%20Park">Mapinguari National Park</a>, a conservation unit created in 2008.
It also contains part of the <a href="Jacund%C3%A1%20National%20Forest">Jacundá National Forest</a>, a sustainable use conservation unit.
The municipality contains 66% of the <a href="Jaci%20Paran%C3%A1%20Extractive%20Reserve">Jaci Paraná Extractive Reserve</a>, created in 1996.
It contains the <a href="Mujica%20Nava%20Ecological%20Station">Mujica Nava Ecological Station</a>, created in 1996.
It contains part of the <a href="Bom%20Futuro%20National%20Forest">Bom Futuro National Forest</a>, established in 1988.
The majority of the forest surrounding Porto Velho has been cut down, however.
Economy.
The <a href="GDP">GDP</a> for the city was R$3,656,512,000 (2005).
The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the city was R$9,779 (2005).
Transportation.
International Airport.
<a href="Governador%20Jorge%20Teixeira%20de%20Oliveira%20International%20Airport">Porto Velho International Airport</a>, 7 km from the city, has its main access at the Av. Governador Jorge Teixeira de Oliveira, with two lanes. Buses from downtown run to the airport every hour, and there is a fleet of taxis serving only the airport. The airport is served by 98 scheduled flights weekly, most going to other large Brazilian cities. The presence of <a href="Porto%20Velho%20Air%20Force%20Base">Porto Velho Air Force Base</a> ensures considerable movement of military aircraft. The local people refer to Porto Velho International as Belmont Airport because it is located in this district. It became an international airport in 2002. It was built as a replacement to <a href="Caiari%20Airport">Caiari Airport</a>, which was closed on April 16, 1969.
<a href="Porto%20Velho%20Air%20Force%20Base">Porto Velho Air Force Base - ALA6</a>, one of their most important bases of the <a href="Brazilian%20Air%20Force">Brazilian Air Force</a>, is located in Porto Velho.
Education.
<a href="Portuguese%20language">Portuguese</a> is the official national language and primary language taught in schools, but <a href="English%20language">English</a> is part of the official <a href="high%20school">high school</a> curriculum.
Culture.
The culture of Porto Velho is marked by a strong <a href="Northeast%20Region%2C%20Brazil">Northeastern</a> influence with <a href="Bumba%20Meu%20Boi">Bumba Meu Boi</a>, the Juninas and Pastorinha peoples, and some influences of south central <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>. The interpretation of <a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Native American</a> legends, such as the <a href="Iara%20%28mythology%29">Iara</a>, the <a href="Boto">Boto</a> and <a href="Mapinguari">Mapinguari</a> <a href="folklore">folklore</a>, influenced by migrants. As for <a href="handicrafts">handicrafts</a>, there are various exhibitions of indigenous works, utilities and adornment using raw materials like <a href="clay">clay</a>, vines, <a href="bamboo">bamboo</a> and <a href="rubber">rubber</a>. The Artisan's House serves as a support to the initiatives of the genre.
Libraries.
The collection of municipal Porto Velho was waiting for his permanent headquarters for several years until recently was completed works of the Municipal Library next to City Hall. The space has two floors with air-cooled in the city center.
Carnival.
The Carnival takes place every year, attracting a large number of people from other cities and states of Rondônia neighbors. During the carnival, there are the parades of carnival and samba schools, which can mention, among the best known, The Diplomats, Asfaltão, among others.
In July Carnival happens Out of Season, with characteristics of the Bahia Carnival, with electric trios and groups Axé.
Theatres.
Two theaters enliven the cultural sector: The Municipal Theater, Avenida Nabuco (center) and Theatre Uirassu Rodrigues, Jose Bonifacio Street.
Museums.
In railway complex, is located the Museum of Railroad Madeira-Mamore, in the city center lies the State Museum, with abundant material on <a href="archeology">archeology</a>, <a href="ethnology">ethnology</a> and <a href="Mineralogy">Mineralogy</a>.
Museum of Railroad Madeira-Mamore.
At the <a href="Museum">Museum</a>, housed in a warehouse loading and unloading almost centenary, one can see hundreds of materials preserved railway. The museum has several pieces from the time of its construction and operation. Besides the first locomotive brought to the Amazon, the Colonel Churchill, we enjoyed also a stork and a tricycle, used to transport the line foremen who fiscalizavam, lathes, machines, furniture, photographs of workers, books, documents and more . The museum is located at Avenida September 7 - Railroad Square Madeira-Mamore. Outside the museum, waterfront, you can take a ride in one of the "barges" to Teotônio waterfall.
Monuments.
The Three Boxes Water.
Also known as The Three Marias, the water tanks are in the center of town, in the square of the same name. The first was erected in 1910 and the other two in 1912 . They were designed and built by Chicago Bridge & Iron Works of Chicago as information contained in cast-iron plate, carved pilasters on each of them. There are three tanks form cylindrical, covered with metal sheets conical shape, and concave shaped base. Each tank is elevated from the floor by four columns made of iron lattice on concrete foundation. They are at the height of the bulge surrounded by a walkway railing with metal lattice through which arrives via a ladder. Each reservoir has a capacity for 200,000 liters and served to supply the city of Porto Velho by the year 1957, working by gravity.
The Cathedral of the Sacred Heart of Jesus.
The Cathedral had its construction initiated in 1917, but was completed only ten years later because of difficulties in transporting material. Original paintings of a religious nature inside the Cathedral, were executed by Father Angelo Cerri and Alfonso Liguori. The stained glass windows that surround it, with the themes of the Cross, were all donated by the community-velhense port.
Sport.
The city has currently seven <a href="Association%20football">football</a> teams: <a href="Clube%20de%20Futebol%20da%20Amaz%C3%B4nia">CF Amazônia</a>, <a href="Cruzeiro%20Esporte%20Clube%20%28RO%29">Cruzeiro EC</a>, <a href="Porto%20Velho%20Esporte%20Clube">Porto Velho EC</a>, <a href="Sport%20Club%20Genus%20de%20Porto%20Velho">SC Genus de Porto Velho</a>, <a href="Sport%20Clube%20Shallon">SC Shallon</a>, <a href="Moto%20Esporte%20Clube">Moto EC</a> and <a href="Rondoniense%20Social%20Clube">Rondoniense SC</a>. In the past the city was also home to <a href="Ferrovi%C3%A1rio%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Clube%20%28RO%29">Ferroviário AC</a>, <a href="Clube%20de%20Regatas%20Flamengo%20%28RO%29">CR Flamengo</a>, <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Domingos%20Esporte%20Clube">São Domingos EC</a>, and <a href="Ypiranga%20Esporte%20Clube">Ypiranga EC</a> before these clubs folded. All clubs share the one stadium in the city, the <a href="Aluiz%C3%A3o">Aluizão</a>, named after <a href="Alu%C3%ADzio%20Ferreira">Aluízio Ferreira</a>, with a smaller ground <a href="Est%C3%A1dio%20Paulo%20Saldanha">Saldanão</a> also available.
